fullProgramDescription: The Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering offers a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering. The program's mission is to educate students to be leaders in the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of infrastructure systems. The curriculum provides a broad foundation in the fundamental principles of civil engineering, including structural analysis and design, transportation systems, water resources engineering, geotechnical engineering, and environmental engineering. Students can choose from a range of technical electives to develop depth in a particular area. The program aims to produce graduates with a strong foundation in engineering principles, problem-solving skills, and the ability to communicate complex ideas effectively.
shortProgramDescription: The Civil Engineering B.S. program at Stanford provides a broad foundation in the fundamental principles of civil engineering and prepares students for leadership roles in the field.
classHighlights: The program begins with foundational courses in Engineering Mechanics (CME100), Mechanics of Fluids (CME211), and Introduction to Environmental Engineering (CEE103A).
Structural analysis and design are covered in courses such as Structural Analysis (CEE102A) and Structural Design (CEE105).

Courses in Transportation Systems (CEE270A/B), Water Resources Engineering (CEE265A/B), Geotechnical Engineering (CEE262A/B), and Environmental Engineering (CEE161A/B) provide a broad introduction to the field.
Students also complete a range of technical electives to develop depth in a particular area, such as structural engineering, transportation systems, or environmental engineering.
The program includes a range of laboratory and design courses, such as Structural Design (CEE105) and Geotechnical Engineering Laboratory (CEE262C).
Students are also required to complete a senior project or other capstone experience, such as CEE195 or CEE196.
Mathematics and science requirements include Calculus I-III (MATH19-21), Differential Equations (MATH51), and Physics (PHYS41/43).
learningOutcomes: Demonstrate a broad understanding of the fundamental principles of civil engineering.
Apply engineering principles to solve complex problems in civil engineering.
Communicate complex ideas effectively in written and oral form.
Design and analyze systems, components, and processes in civil engineering.
Work effectively in teams to solve complex engineering problems.
Understand the social, environmental, and economic context of civil engineering projects.
additionalInformation: Students must declare their major through the School of Engineering. The program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
